urn:contentItem:5PW6-2731-JD34-V3HS-00000-00Burns planned for this weekend2017-11-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisREAL ESTATEBurns planned for this weekend

The Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority will hold planned burns in the Heathcote area this weekend.

A fuel-reduction burn will be completed (with weather permitting) 1.5km south-west of Heathcote on an 18 hectare area in Heathcote-Carboon Lane on Saturday between 1pm and 8pm.

Smoke from the burn may be visible from nearby localities and communities in Heathcote and Argyle and is expected to remain in the area until Tuesday, November 7.

The FFM and CFA have already completed burns in Maiden Gully, Maryborough and Newstead this season.

For more information visit the Forest Fire Management Victoria website at www.ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn

You can also sign up for automated notifications about planned burns near you via www.delwp.vic.gov.au/pbns

urn:contentItem:5R20-XXX1-F0J6-J4N6-00000-00Lightning strike sparks blaze ahead of dangerous fire season2017-11-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 10Lightning strike sparks blaze ahead of dangerous fire season

A lightning strike sparked a blaze in the Lerderderg Gorge this week in a sign that the fire season has begun, authorities say.

The warning comes as the CFA, Forest Fire Management Victoria and Ballarat City Council met recently to discuss the start of the fire danger period, which begins today.

"We saw a number of lightning fires start across the state last Thursday with storms that moved through, one of which is in the Lerderderg," Ballarat-based Forest Fire Management Victoria manager Jasmine Filmer said. "We have crews on it, no issues are anticipated, but it indicates summer is on the way."

Once the fire danger period has been declared, fire restrictions come into force, meaning Ballarat residents cannot light a fire in the open air without a permit.

urn:contentItem:5W25-RWS1-JD34-V35V-00000-00Grampians burn offs2019-05-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Grampians burn offs

Forest Fire Management Victoria began two fuel reduction burns across the Wimmera and Grampians on Monday.

Burns took place around Lake Bellfield and north of Halls Gap, and two more burns will take place at the same times on Tuesday, when 1200 hectares around the Boronia Track and 80 hectares near the Red Gum Lease track will be targeted.

The authority said access may be restricted and visibility may be low.

urn:contentItem:5PTH-RG41-F0J6-J1KY-00000-00East Gippsland on alert2017-10-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6East Gippsland on alert

CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria are introducing fire restrictions for the East Gippsland shire, starting from 1am on Monday, October 16, 2017 to May 1, 2018 unless stated otherwise.

CFA's assistant chief officer Trevor Owen said no fires can be lit on private land without a permit following the introduction of the restrictions.

"To protect community safety, permits are subject to stringent conditions and can be obtained from your CFA District office," Mr Owen said.

"The community needs to be fire ready - especially those living in high risk areas. Fire restrictions are in place for a reason - to help prevent fires from starting."

Forest Fire Management Victoria's assistant chief fire officer, Chris Stephenson said for residents and tourists to prepare their property, themselves and their family for fire.

urn:contentItem:5S0V-RSC1-F0JP-W0T1-00000-00Forest fuel reduction burns start2018-03-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 15Forest fuel reduction burns start

PLANNED burns are set to go ahead in the Otways this long weekend, with appropriate weather conditions predicted.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Darrin McKenzie said some parks, forests and roads may be temporarily closed and holiday-makers are urged to check traffic.vicroads.vic.gov.au for information.

"Forest Fire Management Victoria must take advantage of every safe opportunity to conduct planned burns to reduce bushfire risk for the community. These opportunities can occur during school holidays, public holidays and weekends, such as during this Easter period," he said.

"Over the Easter long weekend, you may see and smell smoke from planned burns, and some roads and parks may close.

"We will be working closely with the Bureau of Meteorology to assess weather conditions, such as humidity, temperature and wind speed, and will only carry out burns when the conditions are suitable."For the latest information about when planned burns are happening, people can visit ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn, download the VicEmergency app or call the VicEmergency hotline on 1800 226 226.

urn:contentItem:5XB4-47W1-JD34-V0CP-00000-00Police investigating car fire in East Bendigo2019-10-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisPolice investigating car fire in East BendigoTara Cosoleto

POLICE are investigating a car fire in East Bendigo on Friday morning.

The Country Fire Authority was called out to the blaze on Victa Road, East Bendigo just before 8.30am.

Crews found an SUV alight but were able to contain the fire.

"We're trying to find out whose car it is at the moment," Bendigo Senior Constable Matt Trist said.

The Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning, and Forest Fire Management are also on scene.

Forest Fire Management Victoria is working with landholders to rehabilitate land around Lake Cobrico impacted by firefighting efforts. Contractors are reinstating fire control lines that were created during the south-west bushfires in March 2018. Otway district manager David Roberts said about six kilometres of open trench was dug on private land around Lake Cobrico to assist efforts during the St Patrick's Day fires.

urn:contentItem:5WFJ-T0N1-JD34-V2F4-00000-00Firewood freeze is looming2019-06-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 2Firewood freeze is loomingTom O'Callaghan

People collecting firewood risk an $8000 fine or one year's jail if they target public land from Sunday. The autumn firewood collection season closes at the end of the month, along with a raft of designated collection areas, Forest Fire Management Victoria's Adrian Parker said. "Firewood is a shared public resource that provides a range of environmental values including land protection, waterway health and habitats for native wildlife, and needs to be managed in a sustainable way for the future," he said.

urn:contentItem:4R5D-X940-TXDB-H01B-00000-00Jarrah forest fire thought to be deliberately lit2007-11-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisJarrah forest fire thought to be deliberately lit

The Department of Environment and Conservation is appealing to the public to come forward with any information about a fire which swept through jarrah forest north of Collie on Friday.

The blaze, which is believed to have been deliberately lit, burnt through about 10 hectares of forest near the Bibbulmun Track.

It took 36 firefighters four hours to contain the blaze.

The department's duty officer, Tom Kenneally, says fire investigators and Collie police believe grass trees were deliberately lit, triggering the blaze.

"At this time we don't have any leads on who may have lit the fire and this is where we would encourage anyone with information regarding this fire to please contact Crime Stoppers," he said.

urn:contentItem:5PG9-NR71-F0JP-W218-00000-00Fire rolls in, locals clear out2017-09-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Fire rolls in, locals clear out

EVER wondered how different animals react during bushfires?

More than 60,000 photographs of native Australians animals have helped experts to determine the impact and severity of fire in their natural habitats.

The Forest Fire Management funded cameras were set up between Lorne and Anglesea over recent months. The data collected from 90 motion-sensing cameras will help experts determine how planned burning can impact wildlife.

Some of the photos of animals were captured at Big Hill, where a 380ha planned burn took place in April.

Forest Fire Management Victoria landscape evaluator Hamish Martin said the project measures the impact of planned burning and will help guide future decisions."The data collected will develop our understanding about how species respond to different types of fire, and this will help guide strategies for future planned burning," Mr Martin said.

urn:contentItem:6005-B4H1-F0J6-J4GR-00000-00Tough battle2019-12-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Tough battleJackson Graham, Katrina Lovell

Firefighters swelter as blazes contained in horror conditions

FIREFIGHTERS sweltered through Monday's "extreme" fire danger as they battled to contain a series of blazes burning in bush near Heywood.

Six fires in the south-west have been burning for 12 days, with one at Lake Condah finally listed as "contained" last night after a day of strong winds and temperatures pushing 40 degrees.

Forest Fire Management incident controller Darren Shiell said that all containment lines had held.

"All fires have crew on them patrolling to make sure hot spots on the containment lines are dealt with,"he said.

Meanwhile, quick-thinking staff helped contain a grass fire at Killarney, which stretched 30 metres along the Princes Highway, blocking traffic for an hour.

But abusive behaviour from some drivers, who ignored warnings and drove through smoke, stunned those who were helping.

urn:contentItem:5R62-CJM1-F0J6-J13V-00000-00Planned burn re-ignited in Ararat Hills Regional Park2017-12-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisPlanned burn re-ignited in Ararat Hills Regional ParkRex Martinich

Forest Fire Management Victoria has advised the Ararat community that it will re-ignite a previous planned burn in bushland north of town.

"We will be re-igniting small patches within the recent Madex Track (Ararat Hills Regional Park) burn perimeter, on Friday afternoon," A Forest fire management statement said.

"Completion is expected on Friday, with crews actively patrolling the area over the weekend.

"Smoke may be visible from Western Highway, about two kilometres north-west of Ararat.

"Thank you for your understanding while we complete this important work."

The planned burn area is about 50 hectares in size.

Firefighters were called to the same area to bring a small bushfire under control about three kilometres north-west of Ararat on Wednesday afternoon.

The fire was declared under control at 5.15pm, about two hours after it was first reported.

A Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning spokesperson said the fire ignited from fuel remaining behind from a planned burn at McDonald Park this month.

urn:contentItem:4N09-GGD0-TX52-N276-00000-00Houses lost in forest fire2007-02-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Houses lost in forest fire

A BUSHFIRE raging in jarrah forest and farmland south-east of Perth has razed 14 houses and has damaged three others.

The fire, which police suspect was deliberately lit on Saturday, last night left the old forestry town of Dwellingup, 70km south-east of Perth, with limited water supplies, while power and telecommunication services were cut when fire destroyed power poles.

The town was relying on mobile generators for emergency power. Fourteen houses and numerous farm sheds outside Dwellingup had been destroyed, and three other houses were damaged by the fire, which has burned more than 4000 hectares of land.

About 100 residents were evacuated to nearby Pinjarrah and Fairbridge.

Environment and Conservation Department spokesman Steve Slavin said more than 250 firefighters were fighting the fire, which was generally contained but still not safe.

Police are investigating the death of a school teacher in her mid-20s who was killed yesterday when her car rolled as she fled a fire near Toodyay, about 85km north-east of Perth.

The woman was thrown from her car, but police said it was unclear whether she was killed as a result of the accident or the bushfire.

urn:contentItem:5PWR-H3H1-F0J6-J1P3-00000-00â€‹ New firefighters undergo training2017-11-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3â€‹ New firefighters undergo trainingAnthony Piovesan

Up to 28 of Forest Fire Management Victoria's newest firefighters underwent a tough and informative training course at St Arnaud last week.

Forest Fire Management Victoria project firefighter coordinator Geoff Tyers said the General Fire Fighter course covered fire behaviour, fire suppression, planned burning, safety and survival techniques.

"The firefighting course is a good mix of classroom and field based activities to get our recruits up to speed with the demands of the fire ground and the varied role of a firefighter," he said.

"The trainees will also conduct a fire event allowing them to practise the theory learned in the classroom.

"It is predicted to be an above-average fire season this year and these project firefighters are very much needed."

All of the seasonal project firefighters for the Loddon Mallee region will be fully trained and operational upon completion of the course.

Stawell residents are encouraged to prepare for the fire danger season as summers draws closer.

urn:contentItem:5NVH-KKF1-JD34-V3H7-00000-00Autumn firewood season to close2017-06-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSAutumn firewood season to closeAnthony Piovesan

THE autumn domestic firewood collection season will end across the state on Friday, June 30.

Forest Fire Management Victoria spokesman Peter Kambouris reminded people who were intending to stock up on firewood for the coming winter to do so before the season closed next week.

"Make sure firewood collection is carried out only from designated collection areas that are open," he said.

"If you need help locating domestic firewood designated collection areas, the Forest Fire Management Victoria website has maps of all sites available at ffm.vic.gov.au."

Mr Kambouris reminded people it was illegal to sell firewood collected on public land without an appropriate permit or licence or to take more than the allowed amount.

The spring firewood collection season will open on September 1.

urn:contentItem:5PWR-H3H1-F0J6-J1KC-00000-00â€‹ New firefighters undergo training2017-11-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3â€‹ New firefighters undergo trainingAnthony Piovesan

Up to 28 of Forest Fire Management Victoria's newest firefighters underwent a tough and informative training course at St Arnaud last week.

Forest Fire Management Victoria project firefighter coordinator Geoff Tyers said the General Fire Fighter course covered fire behaviour, fire suppression, planned burning, safety and survival techniques.

"The firefighting course is a good mix of classroom and field based activities to get our recruits up to speed with the demands of the fire ground and the varied role of a firefighter," he said.

"The trainees will also conduct a fire event allowing them to practise the theory learned in the classroom.

"It is predicted to be an above-average fire season this year and these project firefighters are very much needed."

All of the seasonal project firefighters for the Loddon Mallee region will be fully trained and operational upon completion of the course.

Stawell residents are encouraged to prepare for the fire danger season as summers draws closer.

A BUSHFIRE deep in the North East's high country was contained over the weekend.

The blaze, two kilometres east of Rose River, has covered 2600ha over steep terrain encompassing public and private forests.

Firefighters from Forest Fire Management Victoria and plantation company Hancock's are blacking out areas to stop burning logs and other materials from reigniting the fire.

Residents across the King Valley are warned that smoke will be visible from the fire.

urn:contentItem:5XKN-JGS1-JD34-V3TM-00000-00Lightning and little rainfall a challenge2019-11-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Lightning and little rainfall a challenge

Storms that moved through the North East on Tuesday had emergency services on high alert.

The Beechworth and Yarrawonga SES units were the busiest in the state yesterday morning, an SES spokesman said.

"There were 15 jobs for trees down across the state and another five for building damage," he said.

Trees fell on the Beechworth-Wangaratta Road, Buckland Gap Road, in the Wangaratta township and in Yackandandah.

CFA crews responded to multiple fires caused by lightning strikes, including at Benalla, Boxwood, Howlong and Dartmouth.

Little rain, lightning and strong winds were an issue for firefighters, including those working in sate forests around the region.

Forest Fire Management Victoria has established incident control centres at Tallangatta and Ovens.

The storm front brought with it a dramatic drop in temperature, from 28.6 degrees in Albury at 6.48am on Tuesday to 16 degrees at 8.58am.

urn:contentItem:4KSR-P760-TXDB-H26J-00000-00Chance of El Nino raises forest fire concerns2006-08-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisChance of El Nino raises forest fire concerns

The National Climate Centre is warning of the increased chance of an El Nino weather pattern in eastern Australia by the end of the year.

The weather bureau says higher surface temperatures in the central Pacific Ocean are a strong indication of drier weather to come.

The head of the Climate Centre, Michael Coglin, says the pattern means drought conditions will get worse before they get better.

He says it could also result in more forest fires this summer.

"The fact that the forests are drying out, the tendency when you have these long-term dry spells is that you get serious forest bushfires as opposed to the grassland simply because there hasn't been the growth for the grassland," he said.

urn:contentItem:5P0P-1SK1-DYG0-92BH-00000-00VIC:Feral pigs on the rise in Victoria2017-07-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Feral pigs on the rise in VictoriaMELBOURNE July 11

  Environment authorities are concerned about booming feral pig populations in southwest Victoria.
   Surveillance and trapping undertaken by Forest Fire Management Victoria has confirmed feral pig populations are becoming established in several new locations in the southwest, the department says.


   ?We believe the origin of these newly confirmed populations is most likely through importation and illegal release,"Forest Fire Management Victoria Officer James Downie said on Tuesday.
   "We are seeing evidence of feral pigs that have had their ears cut off consistent with the theory that some pigs were released with the intent of breeding up to allow for increased hunting opportunities."
   While hunting pest animals is permitted in some state forests, cutting off pigs' ears and the use of dogs to chase, hold and attack pigs is prohibited under the animal cruelty act.
   It is also illegal to import, keep, transport or release feral pigs within Victoria.

urn:contentItem:5V8M-FHC1-JD34-V439-00000-00Road fire near Apsley2019-01-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisRoad fire near ApsleyAlexander Darling

FOUR fire trucks attended a fire on the Wimmera Highway near Apsley, which flared up on Friday morning.

Country Fire Authority District 17 operations officer Christian Thorley said crews were alerted at 10am, and received help from Forest Fire Management Victoria to break up and extinguish a pile of wood that ignited during the blaze.

He said police established traffic control near the site while power lines were down.

Fire investigators will look into the blaze.

urn:contentItem:5XB0-M021-F0J6-J2N5-00000-00Planned burn to take place in Kimbolton State Forest2019-10-22T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisWRAPPlanned burn to take place in Kimbolton State ForestChris Pedler

Fire crews from the CFA and Forest Fire Management Victoria will carry out a planned burn in the Kimbolton State Forest.

The burn will be active over Tuesday and Wednesday with smoke expected to be visible until Saturday.

The fuel-reduction burn will be focused on the Kimbolton-Airport Track area.

Smoke may be visible from Kimbolton, Eppalock, Myrtle Creek and Mosquito Creek.

Drivers are advised to take care and obey all traffic signs and instructions from fire crews near the burn.

If you experience and symptoms realted to smoke exposure you should seek medical advice.

Access to walking tracks, camp grounds and picnic sites may be limited.

For more details visit ffm.vic.gov.au/plannedburn

urn:contentItem:5X8X-S271-F0J6-J4N1-00000-00Gannawarra Shire to enter fire danger period2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisGannawarra Shire to enter fire danger period

The fire danger period for the Gannawarra Shire will come into effect from Monday.

During the period, fires cannot be lit in open air without a written permit.

Those who light a fire without a permit can be fined up to $19,000 or receive a 12-month prison sentence.

Read more: Forest Fire Management, Country Fire Authority prepare for the upcoming fire season

Barbecues and fires for cooking and warmth do not require a permit, but must be lit in properly constructed fireplaces.

Fire permits can be obtained by contacting the CFA District 20 headquarters on (03) 5450 9400.

The fire danger period will start on Monday, October 21 and finish on May 1, 2020.

urn:contentItem:5TWB-0H31-JD34-V3CC-00000-00Training for fire recruits2018-12-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Training for fire recruitsChris Pedler

Ninety-four Forest Fire Management Victoria's project firefighters have been recruited to the Loddon Mallee region for fire season - 10 more than usual. - in preparation for bushfires.

They will undertake a second extensive training course this week in Swan Hill.

Covering essential elements including fire behaviour, fire suppression, planned burning, safety and survival techniques, the course is a mix of classroom and field-based activities.

urn:contentItem:5XNG-BKR1-JD34-V49H-00000-00Rainfall helps but fires are still burning2019-12-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Rainfall helps but fires are still burning

RECENT rainfall has dampened several bushfires burning in the North East, but more work is needed to contain the blazes.

Eight fires are still burning in areas including Mt Tawonga and Mt Elmo nearly a fortnight after being sparked by dry lightning.

Rainfall between five and 40 millimetres was recorded at firegrounds at the weekend, but Forest Fire Management Victoria deputy chief fire officer Aaron Kennedy said crews were still busy.

"The rainfall was a welcome relief for firefighters, however, there's still a lot of work to do before we can contain these fires," he said.

"Crews will be working this week to consolidate and patrol containment lines, and to directly attack any hot spots detected through thermal imaging, aerial observation and our network of fire towers.

"Firefighters have worked extremely hard in challenging conditions to manage these fires and reduce their impact on the community and the environment."

None of the fires have threatened homes, but the largest has burnt through 2200 hectares of land.

urn:contentItem:5V9G-BK41-F0J6-J1WN-00000-00Remote fire in border region2019-01-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Remote fire in border region

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews have been working with NSW National Parks and Wildlife Services crews on a number of remote fires in the border region. FFMVic incident controller Steve Young said "bushfires don't respect boundaries". "We've currently got four remote fires totalling approximately 90 hectares in the Byadbo Wilderness Area in the Kosciusko National Park, and another three small fires in the Tingaringy area, immediately south of the border in Victoria, north-east of Tubbut."

urn:contentItem:5V9X-8P41-JD34-V0FF-00000-00Car fire at Green Lake2019-02-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:56:54ZLexisNexisNEWSCar fire at Green LakeAlexander Darling

A man escaped injury after his car caught fire at Green Lake on Wednesday afternoon.

Police say he was driving on a track around the lake when he got bogged and the grass underneath his vehicle caught fire.

The fire eventually burned 12 acres around the Western Highway and Taylors Road. The CFA sent 13 vehicles and two aircraft to bring it under control.

Forest Fire Management Victoria also sent 15 personnel with a bulldozer to take care of nearby hazardous trees.
